hints.content:
There are $\blueD{3}$ rows with $\purpleC{6}$ dots each.

![The same array with the rows numbered 1 through 3 and the dots in the row numbered 1 through 6](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a384a315ea85aa0357cf16188175fd0b8b77d381)

The expression $\blueD{3} \times \purpleC{6}$ represents the array. There are $18$ total dots.

We can group the same array of $18$ dots into columns instead of rows.

There are $\purpleC{6}$ columns with $\blueD{3}$ dots each.

![The same array with the columns numbered 1 through 6 and the dots in the column numbered 1 through 3](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/06cf42dc09c9ca470600dcaf2df9f9847edd368c)

The expression $\purpleC{6} \times \blueD{3}$ also represents the array.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Yes! In a rectangular array, the $\blueD{\text{number of rows}}$ is always the same as the $\blueD{\text{size of the columns}}$. The $\purpleC{\text{number of columns}}$ is always the same as the $\purpleC{\text{size of the rows}}$.

In multiplication, we can switch the factors without changing our total.

$\begin{align}
\blueD{\text{ Number of rows}}\times\purpleC{\text{ size of the rows}} = \greenD{ \text{ total}}\\\\
\purpleC{\text{Number of columns}}\times\blueD{\text{ size of columns}} = \greenD{ \text{ total}}
\end{align}$

We call that pattern the **commutative property of multiplication**.

hints.content: We can represent the array with the expressions $\blueD{3} \times \purpleC{6}$ and $\purpleC{6} \times \blueD{3}$.

question.content:
**Which two expressions represent the following array?**

![An array with 3 rows with 6 dots per row](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/6cd1441393d3e6365da4e2f67befa272d24dbafa)

[[☃ radio 1]]
